Title.evidence: This RCT aimed to compare these two techniques regarding functional and aesthetic outcomes.

Trial_Design.evidence: adult patients undergoing superficial conservative parotidectomy in a single centre for a benign indication were randomized into two equal groups using a closed envelope method.

Participants.evidence: adult patients undergoing superficial conservative parotidectomy in a single centre for a benign indication

Intervention.evidence: In one group, FDFG was inserted at the parotidectomy bed, whereas, in the other group, SMAS flap was performed.

Objective.evidence: This RCT aimed to compare these two techniques regarding functional and aesthetic outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the development of Frey's syndrome.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomized into two equal groups using a closed envelope method.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Seventy-eight patients were randomized into two equal groups of 39 patients.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Seventy-eight patients were randomized into two equal groups of 39 patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference between the two groups regarding development of Frey's syndrome.

Harms.evidence: There was no significant statistical difference between study groups regarding demographic data, co-morbidities, parotid pathologies, specimen volumes, total operating time, and postoperative complications.
